content: The "Secure Fence Act of 2006" requires the Secretary of Homeland Security to achieve operational control over the US borders within 18 months by using surveillance technology and physical infrastructure enhancements. The "Secure Fence Act of 2006" mandates the prevention of unlawful entries into the US, including by terrorists, through operational control measures like checkpoints, access roads, and barriers. The Secretary must report annually on progress towards achieving and maintaining control over international borders. Additionally, the Act calls for the construction of fencing and security improvements along the border from the Pacific Ocean to the Gulf of Mexico. The Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 is amended to include reinforced fencing and additional security measures along the California and Arizona border ports of entry. The Secretary of Homeland Security is tasked with completing fence construction along the Texas border by December 31, 2008. Additionally, a study on the feasibility of a security system along the northern border is required. The Secretary of Homeland Security must evaluate the feasibility and economic impact of implementing a security system along the northern border. A report must be submitted to the relevant committees within one year. Additionally, an evaluation of Customs and Border Protection's authority to stop fleeing vehicles entering the US illegally is required within 30 days of the Act's enactment.
